e1.0.text: Since we’re opening already collected evidence, you just need to fill out the continuity section. Penmanship counts, no duck scratches.

e1.1.text: Oh, and for the description be specific, details matter. If you just write SD card our audit team will personally hunt you down. It’s not just bureaucracy it’s our legal shield.

e1.2.text: And make sure you sign it. That signature binds you to this item until you log it back in, no dropping it in your bag, no taking it home ‘just to check it real quick’. Chain of custody is your legal lifeline.

e2.0.text: Wonderful. Now, glove up. Seriously, no greasy fingerprints on the evidence. We don’t need your DNA on a future Netflix documentary.

e2.1.text: And carefully cut open the bottom of the bag.

e3.0.text: Smooth. Now remember, no direct access. We’ll create a bit-for-bit forensic image using a write blocker, verifying the hash integrity before and after, and then analyse.

e3.1.text: Oh, and pro tip? These little guys are easy to lose. So, document where it is where it’s going, and don’t put it anywhere you wouldn’t put a live grenade.

e3.2.text: Now let’s head back to the desk and see if this card contains a secret database…

e3.3.text: Or just 200 blurry selfies of the suspect's dog.

e4.0.text: Now comes the fun part: Forensic imagining. This is where we create a bit-for-bit copy of the card, preserving every file, fragment, and every bad decision the suspect ever made on it.

e4.1.text: Firstly, by using a write blocker.

e4.2.text: Write blockers are like a bouncer at the club. They let us read what’s inside. But don’t let anything, or anyone, write back. No modification, no accidental changes, no Windows deciding it needs to ‘fix’ the file system.

e4.3.text: First the SD card goes into the write blocker. The data is then fed to our imaging software.

e4.4.text: So, let’s start up the PC by doubling clicking on it, we'll fire up the software and create a forensic image.

e4.5.text: And don't worry, I'll walk you through every step.

e5.0.text: Click on file and select ‘Create Image’. Since we have the physical item, we will be selecting physical drive.

e5.1.text: Now let’s choose the correct target. If you image the wrong drive, say like your own workstation, I will laugh, but also cry.

e5.2.text: We’re going for ‘dd’, we want an exact bit-for-bit copy, without the added fluff embedded.

e5.3.text: Now let's give it a case number, evidence number and description. Remember this should match anything that you wrote on the bag earlier.

e5.5.text: And while we do that, let’s talk hashes. Not the breakfast kind sadly. Cryptographic hashes.

e5.6.text: They’re like digital fingerprints. Before and after we image the card, we calculate a hash, typically MD5 and SHA1.

e5.7.text: Now the software has already automatically generated them for us.

e5.8.text: But it's important to use another tool to double check. Don’t trust the software blindly.

e5.9.text: Even digital tools can lie, especially on a Monday. So, lets run the command line tool.

e6.0.text: Now there are many different hash algorithms such as SHA256 or SHA512, which are much more secure, but also far longer.

e6.1.text: Since the toolkit gave us MD5 and SHA1 we will need to run the script for one of these, to verify it. But feel free to try the others.

e6.2.text: The command is simple, just type 'certutil -hashfile' <the file>' followed by the hash type. Such as MD5.

e6.3.text: Yeah, in this case its named 'SD-image-file.001'.

e7.0.text: Congratulations! You’ve just successfully imaged your first piece of digital evidence.

e7.1.text: You’ll be working from the image going forward. That’s how we protect integrity and ensure reproducibility.

e7.2.text: Now let’s put the SD card safely back into its evidence bag. Press the back button to return to the desk.

e8.0.text: Now, bag that SD card back up, make sure both the old bad and evidence are inside of the new bag.

e8.1.text: Update the new bag to match the information on the old bag. Taking note on who bagged it, the date and time. Then seal it up

e8.2.text: Then it’s on to Phase 2: Analysis. And trust me, that’s where things get…strange.

e9.0.text: Now normally we’d fire up a hex viewer, look for anomalies, maybe peek inside the file system and ask, ‘what are you hiding, tiny storage rectangle?’ But-

e9.1.text: ## Crime scene needs immediate support, suspected network device at a break in. Bring acquisition gear. ##

e9.2.text: And there it is, The Forensic Gods heard you were having a good day and said, ‘nope’.

e9.3.text: Nah, rookie. You’re not cleared for field work ... yet. But you are cleared to lock everything down and go home.

e9.4.text: We’ll pick this up tomorrow. Same dusty office. Less chaos, hopefully.

h2.0.text: Wow that's a lot of blank space. Scrolling would take forever... Let's search for some JPEG signatures.

h2.1.text: Pop quiz time, what's the magic number for a JPEG file?

h2.3.text: Not quiet, that's the signature for a PDF.

h2.4.text: JPEGs will start with FF D8 and are usually followed with FF E0 or FF E1, depending on the metadata. And they end with?

h2.5.text: Afraid not... it's actually FF D9, but close!

h2.6.text: Look at you! That's your JPEG sandwich, FF D8 to FF D9

h2.7.text: Our mission is to find those hex ranges and carve them out manually. Because if the suspect deleted the files but didn't overwrite them, they'll still be hiding in unallocated space like scared ducks.

h2.8.text: Press Ctrl+F and search for the header or footer ~ FF D8 FF or FF D9.

h3.0.text: Nice! Now let's search for the other end of the sandwich.

h3.1.text: But make sure you take note of the offset locations!

h3.2.text: And pay special attention to the offset coordinates, the top bar will change the last character on the offset.

h4.0.text: Bingo, let's mark the byte offset at the start and end.

h4.1.text: Press Ctrl+E and we'll select the block as a new file. Remember to include the full footer signature ~ FF D9 in your selection.

h5.0.text: Now let's save it as a .jpg. If you've carved it correctly, you'll be able to open it and view the image.

h6.0.text: Huh... it just looks like some vacation photo.

h6.1.text: Let's keep carving, see if there's any more JPEG files to uncover.

h6.2.text: Well, they weren't visible through the file system. Probably deleted. Maybe even intentionally hidden.

h6.3.text: And now, its back from the digital graveyard, because you carved it out like a forensic necromancer.

h6.4.text: It is. Welcome to the part of digital forensics where persistence pays off. Most people give up after they don't see obvious files. We go further, byte by byte.

h6.5.text: Now document everything. The image file it came from, the byte offsets, the file type signature, the software used, and the chain of custody log.
option display: On it, should I keep searching?

h6.6.text: Keep your eyes peeled for anything that screams, 'I shouldn't be here'. The digital underground is a strange, messy place.

h7.0.text: Hmm, that looks like all of them.

h7.1.text: Good work. You've gone from 'just imaged an SD card' to 'manually carving images out of raw hex' in under 48 hours.

h7.2.text: That's faster than some interns figure out how to open the evidence locker.

h8.0.text: But it doesn't stop there. Just because the photos don't look incriminating, doesn't mean that's the case.

h8.2.text: Every image, especially from phones or digital cameras leaves behind EXIF data.

h8.3.text: That's GPS, timestamps, device make and model, even exposure settings.

h8.4.text: But first let's take five. You've earned it.

h8.5.text: ## Digital forensics, please respond. We've got a warehouse break-in, possible tampered security DVR. Imaging requested ASAP. ##

h8.6.text: You've got to be kidding me.
option display: Do I go with you this time?

h8.7.text: Still no, not until you're certified to touch anything more complex than a Raspberry Pi.

h8.8.text: But! Lock down your carved images, export the logs, and back up everything to the secure case directory. We'll dive into metadata tomorrow. Bright and early.

m1.0.text: First open one of the images we carved yesterday

m2.0.text: Let's look at the key fields, such as when and where the photo was taken.

m2.1.text: If you want more information on any of the fields first select the question mark in the top right and then select a key.

m2.2.text: If there is any metadata that you think doesn't match just select both keys to compare them.

m3.0.text: Nice work, lets open the next image.

m4.0.text: Ahuh. Photoshop. Possible tampering. Add it to the notes.

m4.1.text: That alone won't convict anyone, but it tells us what direction to push during interrogation

m5.0.text: 51 degrees north and 1 degree east, that would make it time zone UTC

m6.0.text: Huh this shows that the GPS time is 10 hours ahead of the recorded date time. That would make it time zone UTC-10.

m7.0.text: So, to review, you carved hidden files from raw hex, extracted the metadata, finding the timestamps and GPS data. AND you didn't overwrite, alter, or spill coffee on any evidence.

m7.1.text: You're either a natural... or I am finally getting better at training people. Either way, we're making progress.

m7.2.text: Now, go document everything. Then, we prep for full report drafting. The brass upstairs like their timelines clean, their evidence referenced and their conclusions airtight.

m8.0.text: And remember digital forensics isn't just about finding the evidence. It's about proving you didn't change the evidence while finding it.

m8.1.text: ## Digital Forensics, we've got a priority call, active scene. Suspected mobile device tampering. Location enroute. ##

m8.2.text: Do they wait until we've hit a rhythm?

m8.3.text: You know the drill. Go home and we'll wrap this up in the morning with the final report.

m7.3.text: Excellent. Now we verify the hashes. Think of it as digital insurance. If those files ever end up in court the opposing sie will try to claim they were altered. We need proof they weren't

m7.4.text: Run the hash on both the original forensic image an the carved JPEGs.

m7.5.text: That's the standard these days. But MD5 and SHA1 is what we used previously, so let's stay consistent

m7.6.text: MD5 is fast, but tends to be vulnerable to collisions. So typically more complex hash algorithms are used, but since MD5 and SHA1 is what we used previously we'll use it this time as well to stay consistent.

m7.7.text: Let's start with the forensic image file

m8..text: Nice, it matches the hash from acquisition, meaning you haven't tampered with it.

m81..text: Now, let's hash each of the carve images and record those too

m9..text: Perfect. Those hashes will go into your final report. If anyone questions whether those files were modified after extraction, you can show that the hash is identical to the one you recorded right after carving.
